newsitem.title: GREECE: Evert re-elected Greece's opposition leader.
newsitem.headline: Evert re-elected Greece's opposition leader.

text.p: Miltiadis Evert was re-elected leader of Greece's conservative opposition New Democracy party on Friday, defeating challenger George Souflias.
Party officials said Evert, who resigned as leader last week after a national election defeat, received 103 votes from party delegates to 84 for Souflias.
"We are turning a new page," Evert told reporters after his victory. "No one lost. There are no winners or losers."
Evert resigned as party president after losing elections on September 22, saying he was assuming responsibility for New Democracy's failure to oust the ruling socialists.
A stocky, outspoken former mayor of Athens, Evert was blamed for the election defeat by many conservatives who said his populist style had failed to inspire voters.
The serious, professorial speeches of the socialist Prime Minister Costas Simitis, appeared more convincing than Evert's fist-banging oratory.
The election returned the socialists to power with a strong absolute majority in parliament despite opinion poll predictions of a neck-and-neck race.
Evert's resignation ignited a fierce leadership battle in New Democracy, with many young members rushing to declare their candidacy.
But new faces, such as Dora Bakoyianni and Constantine Karamanlis, dropped out, leaving Souflias, a former education and national economy minister, as Evert's only challenger.
"There are people in every town, in every village, who are telling us to set bickering aside and look at the problems the country is facing," Evert said.
